revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/66.7.250.42|66.7.250.42]] ([[User talk:66.7.250.42|talk]]) to last revision by FlowerTeam25 ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
[[File:Panes au solea pousse Marok.jpg|thumb|Solar powered well in Rhamna, near [[Marrakech]]]] [[File:SolarGIS-Solar-map-Morocco-en.png|thumb|Solar resources in Morocco]] [[File:DESERTEC-Map large.jpg|thumb|[[Desertec]] plan]] '''Solar power in Morocco''' is enabled by the country having one of the highest rates of solar [[insolation]] among other countries— about 3,000 hours per year of sunshine but up to 3,600 hours in the desert. [[Morocco]] has launched one of the world’s largest solar energy projects costing an estimated $9 billion. The aim of the project is to create 2,000 megawatts of solar generation capacity by the year 2020.<ref>[http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-16983-afdb-helps-fund-144bn-moroccan-solar-project/ AfDB helps fund $1.44bn Moroccan solar project]</ref> Five solar power stations are to be constructed, including both [[photovoltaic]] and [[concentrated solar power]] technology. The Moroccan Agency for Solar Energy (MASEN), a public-private venture, has been established to lead the project. The first plant will be commissioned in 2015,<ref>[http://ecogeek.org/component/content/article/3770 Morocco Building 500 MW Solar Power Project]</ref> and the entire project in 2020. Once completed, the solar project will provide 38% of Morocco’s annual electricity generation.
Morocco, the only [[Africa]]n country to have a power cable link to [[Europe]] (2,100 MW <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ozabs-morocco-spain-cable-idAFJOE5A80T420091109|title=Morocco to upgrade power link with Spain|last=Farge|first=Emma|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-11-22|language=en-US}}</ref>), aims to benefit from the €400bn ($573.8bn) expected to come from the ambitious pan-continental [[Desertec|Desertec Industrial Initiative]].
== Ouarzazate solar plant == {{main|Ouarzazate solar power station}} The Moroccan Agency for Solar Energy invited expressions of interest in the design, construction, operation, maintenance and financing of the first of the five planned solar power stations, the 500 MW complex in the southern town of [[Ouarzazate]], that includes both [[photovoltaics|PV]] and [[concentrated solar power|CSP]]. Construction officially began on 10 May 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://phys.org/news/2013-05-morocco-solar-mega-project-ouarzazate.html |title= Morocco launches solar mega-project at Ouarzazate |website= phys.org |date= 10 May 2013 |publisher= AFP |accessdate= 1 August 2014 |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/6RV927aDp |archivedate= 1 August 2014}}</ref> The project is divided in 3 phases: a 160MW [[concentrated solar power]] project, a 200MW [[solar thermal#Parabolic trough designs|parabolic mirror]] plant, and a 150MW [[solar trough]] plant.<ref>Construction begins on 160 MW CSP plant in Morocco, pv-magazine.com/news/details/beitrag/construction-begins-on-160-mw-csp-plant-in-morocco-_100011255/#axzz3OWLu4WTY</ref><ref>[http://gulfbusiness.com/2015/01/saudis-acwa-power-wins-1-7bn-euro-morocco-solar-power-deal/#.VLJ4byvF_8Z Saudi’s ACWA Power Wins 1.7bn Euro Morocco Solar Power Deal], Reuters, January 10, 2015</ref>
The 160 MW first phase, ''Noor I'', was brought online in February 2016.<ref name="World's largest concentrated solar plant switches on in the Sahara">{{cite web|last3=Park|first3=Phoebe|title=World's largest concentrated solar plant switches on in the Sahara|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/02/08/africa/ouarzazate-morocco-solar-plant/|website=cnn.com|accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref> The project was awarded to a consortium led by Saudi Arabia's [[Al-Muhaidib#ACWA_Power|ACWA Power]], which sells the electricity produced for $0.19/kW·h, and co-financed by the [[World Bank]] and the [[European Investment Bank]].<ref>[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/saudi-led-consortium-wins-morocco-solar-energy-bid-153652570--finance.html Saudi-led consortium wins Morocco solar energy bid]</ref> The second phase, the 200 MW ''Noor 2'' plant, came online in January 2018, and the third phase is expected to come online by the end of 2018. These two phases provide another 580 MW and cover 6,000 acres.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jamie|first1=Condliffe|title=Morocco Switches On First Phase Of The World's Largest Solar Plant|url=https://gizmodo.com/morocco-switches-on-first-phase-of-the-worlds-largest-s-1757281810|website=GIZMODO|accessdate=8 February 2016}}</ref>
== Morocco Renewable Energy projects now-2030 == Morocco Renewable Energy solar projects to be installed between now and 2030
{| class="wikitable sortable" |+ !Name !Output !Location !Technology !Status !Notes |- |[[Ain Beni Mathar Integrated Thermo Solar Combined Cycle Power Plant|Ain Beni Mathar]] |400MW |[[Ain Bni Mathar]] |[[Parabolic trough]] | |Also runs on fossil fuels (Gas) |- |[[Noor I]] |160 [[Megawatt|MW]] |[[Drâa-Tafilalet]] |[[Parabolic trough]] | |Part of [[Ouarzazate Solar Power Station]] |- |Noor II |200 [[Megawatt|MW]] |[[Drâa-Tafilalet]] |[[Parabolic trough]] | |Part of [[Ouarzazate Solar Power Station]] |- |Noor III |150 MW |[[Drâa-Tafilalet]] |[[solar power tower]] | |Part of [[Ouarzazate Solar Power Station]] |- |Noor IV |70 MW |[[Drâa-Tafilalet]] |[[Photovoltaics]] | |Part of [[Ouarzazate Solar Power Station]] |- |Sebkhate Tah |500MW | | | | |- |Foum Al-Oued |500MW | | | | |- |Boujdour |100 MW | | |Planned | |- |Noor Midelt |800 MW | | | | |- |Noor PV II |800MW |Taroudant, Kalâat Seraghna, Bejaâd, Guercif, El Hajeb | | | |- |Noor-Tafilalet |120 M |Zagora, Erfoud and Missour | |Planned | |- |Noor Atlas |800MW |Tata/Tahla/Tan Tan/Outat El Haj/Ain Beni Mathar/Boudnib/Bouanane/Boulemane |[[Photovoltaics]] | | |- |Noor Argana |200 MW |Boumalne/Tinghir/Errhamna/Essaouira |[[Photovoltaics]] | | |}
